intro: Aidema bifolia, commonly known as the two-leaved aidema, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its simple, opposite leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers that bloom in spring. It typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in partial to full sunlight. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it remains relatively rare in horticultural trade.
